STRINGS: "You're... Blindman, aren't you?"
"Again, pleased to meet you.
I am the 'Blindman' you have been looking for
for so long."
She chuckled.
Her expression practically said, 'I completely strung you along'.
"Did you think I was male--? It's no surprise.
After all, there's a 'man' right there in the name."
Her lips stretched sideways to their limit,
and while she showed me a radiant smile,
something in the depths of her pupils seemed to have possessed her.
"Looks like you noticed it too late.
You're already dead, you know?"
I had no doubts she was directing her murderous impulses towards me.
Do I have no means to escape this predicament?
Only my lips and tongue are fuctioning, even if barely.
All I can rely upon is my own rhetoric.
If even these lips and tongue stop working,
then I'll simply die in this wretched room reeking of dust and rot.
At the very least, talking with her
should buy me some time, no matter how small.
Forcing my brain, which was paralyzed at the prospect of dying,
to operate at maximum capacity, I narrowly located the words
I ought to utter.
"Are... are you going to kill me now?"
"Huh? That's a strange thing to ask.
Why would you ask such a question at this stage?"
"Because, well, uhm."
If I vacillate even for a second, it'll be over for me.
Once her interest in her captive, me, runs dry,
I'll be disposed of into that bucket.
"It's like you haven't given up even in these conditions...
Fufufu, you're so tenacious, Ms. Houjou."
She suddenly brought her face up to my ear.
Then she whispered to me in a nearly imperceptible volume.
"Please resign yourself already...
Wait, maybe you should try fighting back...
There's no fun to be had with someone who gave up on everything."
Perhaps intentionally, she eagerly tried to throw me off balance.
I'm sure she wanted to make me feel fear.
Blindman-- Sanae Makimura loved to play
with human lives that were in the palm of her hand.
"I'm frustrated, that's all."
"Frustrated? What is that supposed to mean?"
"I found the mastermind behind the serial killings.
Blindman is you.
But that's it."
"That alone won't suffice, I want to know the full truth.
Why did you turn to crime?
Until I know that, I cannot afford to die."
Yet again, she chuckled.
As though she couldn't help but find my actions funny.
"In other words, as long as you can learn everything,
you won't care about what happens to you.
Is that what you mean?"
"Right now, satisfying your interest wouldn't change anything.
You will die and Blindman will live.
I'm sure you won't be discovered for a long time to come."
"Regardless, this case is nowhere near being fully elucidated.
If I stopped killing after disposing of you due to a whim or whatever,
decades might pass without this case being solved."
"Even if you learned everything now,
I wouldn't let you bring it to the light of day!
In spite of that, do you still want to know???"
"E-even so..."
"Please speak up now.
I might not look like it, but I have little patience."
"Even so, I can't just die and leave things as is."
"Ufufu. Kihihihi...
...You're a strange woman, Ms. Houjou."
"I'm backup personnel from a window-gazing department
that doesn't even have windows, after all.
I was assigned to babysit an annoying murderer.
The station treats us like nutcases."
"That's not what I mean.
Other people wouldn't act like you.
The instant I grab a tool, they void their bowels."
"They cry and they wail and they beg for their lives.
And so I cut off their tongues before anything else, as usual."
"Without any anesthetics, naturally. They're going to die either way.
But it's not like the facility pays me enough.
I couldn't buy some even if I wanted."
"I can't get ahold of any to begin with,
and even if I could use them, it surely would be traced back to me.
The police are quite persistent. Wouldn't you agree?"
"Certainly, if we detected anesthetics during the autopsy,
we would consider investigating their routes of distribution."
"Indeed, indeed.
I'm so glad I hit the mark."
She was in ecstasy at her thought process being proven right.
She probably wanted to know just how much
her crimes outsmarted the police.
As a result, the conversation was slightly derailed.
What I want to know is the whole of the truth.
Not some minute event that bothered her.
"Please go back on topic.
Why did you call me strange?"
"Ah, excuse me.
It's because you wouldn't even plead for your life."
"Are you not afraid of dying by my hand, Ms. Houjou?"
"Of course I'm afraid.
But what's much scarier is--"
"--Knowing nothing."
"Is that so...? Alright.
Then, how about this: instead of telling you what you want to know,
I just slice your ears off?"
"Fufu... hehehe."
I cracked up in spite of myself.
It's not that I was going crazy from fear.
My head was actually becoming clearer by the minute.
"...Why are you laughing?"
"I just thought you were strange as well.
You're going to kill me regardless, aren't you?"
"Then you don't need to ask me about every little thing."
"Quite so.
I wanted to know whether you were hardy or not."
"Fair enough. I'll tell you.
Are you okay with listening to such a long story?"
I nodded.
She went out of her way to ask permission first,
but I had no say in the situation, in any case.
While aimlessly fiddling with the tool in her hand,
she sat down next to me.
"I'm really not that patient.
I tend to find things bothersome and I can't help but want
to avoid them. At the same time, I've lived my life being
swept away by various things."
"I can't control my emotions well, I seriously can't.
I'm weak to pressure and I often panic during hard times."
"Once I fell into these conditions and the switch flipped,
I couldn't help myself anymore..."
"Oh, but I didn't immediately start killing people... I think.
There was still some steps before that."
"Falling to pressure was a daily part of my life.
I once bought three newspapers.
I had a hard time turning down solicitations and stuff..."
She laughed at herself charmingly.
If this was a talk at a downtown tea shop, the other customers
would've mistaken us for friends talking about our worries.
"...Mr. Kanaya was like that, too."
"Hiromu Kanaya was?"
"Yeah. He was.
Mr. Kanaya took advantage of my weakness.
I couldn't refuse him no matter how much I wanted..."
"But, oh, how I hated those days of being toyed around with...
I was in anguish for some time,
unable to muster the courage to refuse."
"What weakness did Kanaya exploit against you?"
My head had gotten the tiniest bit muddled.
I couldn't quite see the full picture of this drama only she knew,
nor could I connected it back to the particulars of the case I knew.
At my inquiry,
she suddenly came to her senses.
"I'm sorry. This must have sounded nonsensical.
Let me properly recount it from the beginning.
It all starts with Mr. Takenaka."
--The man who lived in public housing in the lonely outskirts
of town and was brutally murdered together with his family,
Shin'ichirou Takenaka.
From the state of the cadavers' injuries,
we listed them as the first victims to be killed by Blindman.
"He was studying urban legends at graduate school.
We happened to meet as he came back to town,
and from then on we began seeing each other."
"At the beginning, everything was normal.
I wasn't doing anything, nor did I kill anyone.
I was 'pristine', so to speak."
"My relationship was harmonious with Mr. Takenaka.
He even supported my dream of becoming
a qualified caregiver."
"It was outside Mr. Takenaka's area of expertise,
yet we would study together to qualify for caregiving.
He, too, was a normal but extremely kind man."
"I felt a faint darkness within that gentleness,
but that made him even more charming.
Thinking back upon it now, that was the happiest period of my life..."
"But those joyful days didn't last long.
Something in Mr. Takenaka's demeanor changed."
"It was a really trivial change.
When I broke an appointment, his emotions would fluctuate wildly.
But those minor changes steadily began to pile up every time we met."
"His behavior was like... like some great anguish
was crushing him little by little."
"After all this time, I still don't know if that anguish was
the pain of being unable to find a job back in your home town,
the loneliness of having no other relationships outside of
his family and me, or anything else."
"But what was evident was that
The pool of anxiety that boiled within Mr. Takenaka
was gradually changing him..."
After talking for this long without pause,
she caught a single breath, 'phoo'.
But the whole true I wanted to hear
was still a far cry off.
I wouldn't be able to handle it if she killed me in this halfway point.
Perhaps catching onto that feeling,
she moved her lips again.
"Mr. Takenaka was a pervert."
The sudden left turn in the conversation made me shout unintentionally.
"Are you wondering, what sort of pervert?"
"N-not at all. I don't want to hear those kinds of details."
"I don't think it's that graphic a story.
It might not match your expectations,
but it's fine, isn't it? You'll be dying either way."
"His perversion came after thoroughly roughing me up on a futon
with a single sliding screen separating us from his parents."
"He would rattle on about all kinds of odd things
right into my ears as I breathed heavily."
"'I was studying urban legends.
I memorized urbans legends from all over the country.
But among them, the most interesting featured otherwordly monsters.'"
"'There are these terrifying monsters in urban legends.
Such frightening rumors. They're unlike simple talk of ghosts.
A miniscule sense of reality is at their core.'"
"'Hanako of the Toilet and the Man-faced Dog--'"
"'The Ningen in Antarctica, alligators lurking in the sewers--
They all have a fascinating precariousness that
makes them seem like they could happen in the real world.'"
"I asked him why would he study such repulsive things.
Then Mr. Takenaka grinned evocatively."
"'I'm just a trifler in this oh-so-wide world.
I was obsessed with urban legends
and charmed by the man who gave his life to them."
"No way, is that--?"
I remembered Shin'ichirou Takenaka's profile.
"--Indeed. It was Professor Soujirou Sekimoto."
"Mr. Takenaka would always say this about Professor Sekimoto:
'The professor's research is the devil's work. I can't match him.'
--and other similar comments."
"'The greatest monster the professor invented--
--That is Blindman.'"
"'It'll come after me one day.
Blindman will come.'"
"Since he keep mumbling Blindman's name over and over,
I inquired into what that was, and he kindly told me many times
just how dreadful a being it was as carefully as he could."
"Blindman was a urban legend fabricated on purpose
to be a subject of study by Professor Sekimoto."
"This man would come out every night,
stabbing out the eyes of solitary passersby to take away their vision."
"Then he would hide a message inside the victim's mouth.
'Give me your eyes', it said.
Whoever discovered it would become his next target..."
"Mr. Takenaka told me so again and again,
always arbitrarily fearing its shadow.
He'll be killed one of these days, he had no doubt he would--"
"So he did the things he wanted to do in the moment.
Because he no longer would be able to once he died.
As I looked at the man before me, I realized something."
"Ah, he wants to die, doesn't he?"
"I had no basis for that. It was just intuition.
But he feared death and constantly expressed that fear,
so much that I felt he had given up on living."
"However, Mr. Takenaka was a coward who could choose suicide.
He was all talk, unable to carry out anything to the end."
"Yet he kept doing horrible things to me...
Confronted by his half-hearted desire for destruction,
an idea came to mind."
"If he's going to be afraid of Blindman's shadow forever,
if anything, he would be relieved to see him in reality."
"Those were the events that led to the current state of that house.
And since nobody lived around them,
I had plenty of time until you found them out, Ms. Houjou."
"But Shin'ichirou Takenaka wasn't the only corpse there.
You made victims out of his parents, too.
Why kill them as well?"
"Oh, that?
It's simple. Because they looked like
they wanted to die themselves."
"Do you recall how that region was?
That public housing district became deserted land due to depopulation.
And they lived there all alone, quietly waiting for death to come."
"They gave up for some reason, and merely kept living in silence.
So wouldn't they be happier dying as a family?"
"...An arbitrary notion by itself."
"I think so myself, to be honest.
But after that day, I felt like I was reborn."
"I broke a taboo you must never break as a human.
The indescribable guilt and pleasure that followed tingled me.
As a matter of fact, I remember being awfully aroused."
"Afterwards, I admired the now-quiet house absentmindedly,
and just as I went outside in high spirits--"
"I was witnessed. By Mister Hiromu Kanaya.
Their spurts of blood had painted me bright red.
Genuinely, I resigned myself, thinking it was all over."
"However and fortunately, Mr. Kanaya didn't report me."
"Instead, he photographed my bloodstained form with his cell phone.
With that as his shield, new days of being threatened by him began."
...This is horrible.
From beginning to end, it's just horrible.
Every person she described--
--including Sanae Makimura herself--
had some part of their humanity warped and perverted.
